description: Multiple trips down the shore over the last two weeks brought back a dozen new coronavirus cases in Bucks County, health officials say. Eleven of the county's 33 new cases reported Saturday evening were linked to one New Jersey resident who contracted the virus at a beach house gathering recently, a county news release states. Another previously identified...
text:
Multiple trips down the shore over the last two weeks brought back a dozen new
coronavirus cases in Bucks County, health officials say.

Eleven of the county's 33 new cases reported Saturday evening were linked to
one New Jersey resident who contracted the virus at a beach house gathering
recently, a county news release states.

Some of those 11 people came into contact with that person while they also
visited the shore, then spread the highly contagious virus to several others
when they returned.

County Health Department Director Dr. David Damsker said the new cases
highlight the importance of caution as the county was only a day into the
second phase of the state's reopening plan.

"This is exactly why we can't let our guard down now, even if it feels 'safe'
to be at the beach," Damsker said Saturday.

Another previously identified patient in Bucks County was also linked to the
same New Jersey resident as the county worked on tracing the source of the 11
new cases.

The county has not released the specific area of the shore the new patients
were visiting for confidentiality reasons.

"One unlucky exposure can lead to a large cascade of cases down the line. We
want everyone to enjoy the warmer weather and have fun, but let's keep in mind
that COVID is still circulating in the community at baseline levels," Damsker
added.

New Jersey beaches reopened late last month.

In Pennsylvania, the three-phased, color-coded reopening plan was announced in
late April, a plan Gov. Tom Wolf said would be guided by new cases, hospital
capacity and other factors.

Most counties moved out of the initial red phase and into the yellow phase
through May, but Bucks, Montgomery and several other southeastern counties
remained in the red phase until Friday.

The yellow phase of reopening lifts stay-at-home orders and allowed certain
businesses to reopen where direct contact between customers and employees
could be avoided.

Yet state and local health officials warned against the possibility of
backsliding into the red should spikes in cases be seen.

New cases reported in both the state and the county have been on a general
downward trend in recent weeks, with most new cases occurring in nursing home
residents and staff, or in health care workers.

State Department of Health spokesman Nate Wardle echoed past comments from
Wolf and Health Secretary Dr. Levine to residents that the yellow phase should
be treated as a cautionary step forward.

"... this is the type of concerning development that we will see as people
(increase) their interactions with the stay-at-home order lifted," Department
of Health spokesman Nate Wardle said in an email Monday.

"We need people to continue to wear masks, to continue to maintain social
distancing and to take precautions as they travel out," Wardle added.

Based on past statements from the state, a spike in cases alone would not take
Bucks or other counties into the red again.

Moving between phases has depended on multiple factors, one of the biggest
concerns being how a county's healthcare system can respond to an outbreak in
new cases.

An uptick in coronavirus cases could be coming in the near future as Wolf
announced Monday morning a universal testing mandate for nursing homes and
long-term care facilities.

The order requires nursing homes to test all residents and employees
regardless of symptoms.

"We are working tirelessly to include all long-term care facilities in this
strategy as soon as possible," Levine said in a Monday news release.

The state health department estimates 615 facilities across the state have
seen cases of the virus in over 16,000 residents and over 2,800 employees as
of Monday.

Nearly 70% of the state's 5,953 coronavirus-related deaths have been related
to infections in nursing homes.

The state issued a pilot program between May 11 and May 26 implementing
universal testing in five facilities across the state.

At least 75 facilities have also performed universal testing that has
ultimately seen the percentage of infected lower.

The state will be taking requests for testing supplies directly from nursing
homes, which will have until July 24 to complete the testing.

"At this point, we are able to successfully expand testing and support to all
staff and residents to further protect those in nursing homes across
Pennsylvania," Levine added.

As of Monday, almost 76,000 people in Pennsylvania are estimated to have
contracted coronavirus since March 6.

title: A dozen new Bucks County coronavirus cases linked to New Jersey resident
html:
Multiple trips down the shore over the last two weeks brought back a dozen new coronavirus cases in Bucks County, health officials say.

Eleven of the county's 33 new cases reported Saturday evening were linked to one New Jersey resident who contracted the virus at a beach house gathering recently, a county news release states.

Some of those 11 people came into contact with that person while they also visited the shore, then spread the highly contagious virus to several others when they returned.

County Health Department Director Dr. David Damsker said the new cases highlight the importance of caution as the county was only a day into the second phase of the state's reopening plan.

"This is exactly why we can't let our guard down now, even if it feels 'safe' to be at the beach," Damsker said Saturday.

Another previously identified patient in Bucks County was also linked to the same New Jersey resident as the county worked on tracing the source of the 11 new cases.

The county has not released the specific area of the shore the new patients were visiting for confidentiality reasons.

"One unlucky exposure can lead to a large cascade of cases down the line. We want everyone to enjoy the warmer weather and have fun, but let's keep in mind that COVID is still circulating in the community at baseline levels," Damsker added.

New Jersey beaches reopened late last month.

In Pennsylvania, the three-phased, color-coded reopening plan was announced in late April, a plan Gov. Tom Wolf said would be guided by new cases, hospital capacity and other factors.

Most counties moved out of the initial red phase and into the yellow phase through May, but Bucks, Montgomery and several other southeastern counties remained in the red phase until Friday.

The yellow phase of reopening lifts stay-at-home orders and allowed certain businesses to reopen where direct contact between customers and employees could be avoided.

Yet state and local health officials warned against the possibility of backsliding into the red should spikes in cases be seen.

New cases reported in both the state and the county have been on a general downward trend in recent weeks, with most new cases occurring in nursing home residents and staff, or in health care workers.

State Department of Health spokesman Nate Wardle echoed past comments from Wolf and Health Secretary Dr. Levine to residents that the yellow phase should be treated as a cautionary step forward.

"... this is the type of concerning development that we will see as people (increase) their interactions with the stay-at-home order lifted," Department of Health spokesman Nate Wardle said in an email Monday.

"We need people to continue to wear masks, to continue to maintain social distancing and to take precautions as they travel out," Wardle added.

Based on past statements from the state, a spike in cases alone would not take Bucks or other counties into the red again.

Moving between phases has depended on multiple factors, one of the biggest concerns being how a county's healthcare system can respond to an outbreak in new cases.

An uptick in coronavirus cases could be coming in the near future as Wolf announced Monday morning a universal testing mandate for nursing homes and long-term care facilities.

The order requires nursing homes to test all residents and employees regardless of symptoms.

"We are working tirelessly to include all long-term care facilities in this strategy as soon as possible," Levine said in a Monday news release.

The state health department estimates 615 facilities across the state have seen cases of the virus in over 16,000 residents and over 2,800 employees as of Monday.

Nearly 70% of the state's 5,953 coronavirus-related deaths have been related to infections in nursing homes.

The state issued a pilot program between May 11 and May 26 implementing universal testing in five facilities across the state.

At least 75 facilities have also performed universal testing that has ultimately seen the percentage of infected lower.

The state will be taking requests for testing supplies directly from nursing homes, which will have until July 24 to complete the testing.

"At this point, we are able to successfully expand testing and support to all staff and residents to further protect those in nursing homes across Pennsylvania," Levine added.

As of Monday, almost 76,000 people in Pennsylvania are estimated to have contracted coronavirus since March 6.
